quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Imagine that you're walking home from work, you see this bright, shiny object, and you realize it's a magic lamp. And you rub the lamp and this genie comes out and the genie says, "Hey, I can give you one wish. Whatever you throw yourself into with your whole life and your career, it's going to turn out great." If that were true and you had that genie, what would you wish for? At some point in this one life we get, you want to get yourself on that path of that journey.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Introduces the “genie” thought experiment as a practical framework for clarifying what path you’d choose if success were guaranteed.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You're unconscious, and you may not even realize why you're doing what you're doing or even realize what you're doing. So for example, I get up, work out, drive into work, fight traffic, commute, maybe I return some emails, fight traffic on the way home, rush through dinner, go to bed. It's not a day that is intentional. It's not a day where I've said, "Where do I want to be going with my life? What's important to me in this world?"
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Defines “autopilot” with a concrete daily loop and contrasts it with intentional living guided by explicit priorities.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Everything that you want is on the other side of worse first.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that reframes early discomfort as a necessary gateway to meaningful improvement.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Pick anything. You want a better body? Okay, you're going to need to go to the gym. When you go to the gym the first few times, it's going to not be that fun. The first move is negative. If I'm optimizing for tomorrow and I just want to have a great day tomorrow, I'm going to stay exactly where I am. So many people I see have this happen, where they hit a plateau and they never move past it, because they're not willing to have that hard day, month, week, year.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Explains why progress often feels worse at first and how short-term optimization traps people on plateaus.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Their single API helps SaaS companies launch over 200 product integrations in weeks, not quarters.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark and approach (single API) for dramatically accelerating integration delivery timelines.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Think of Merge like Plaid, but for everything B2B SaaS.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable analogy that frames a platform strategy for integrations via a familiar mental model.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Organizations like Ramp, Dorada and Electric use Merge to access their customers' accounting data to reconcile bill payments, file storage data to create searchable databases in their product, or HRAS data to auto-provision and deprovision access for their customers' employees.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Specific real-world examples of integration use cases practitioners can map to their own product needs.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: What sets Persona apart is its configurability.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a key product principle—configurability—as a differentiator when requirements vary by context and risk.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: That's why Persona offers flexible building blocks that allow you to build tailored collection and verification flows that maximize conversion while minimizing risks.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: An actionable design approach: use modular building blocks to balance conversion and risk in identity workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Why students ask: what should I do?
quotes.text: About half of all the times I meet with students, that's the question they ask.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A concrete data point showing how often high-achieving students seek life-direction guidance rather than tactical business advice.

quotes.topic_title: Why students ask: what should I do?
quotes.text: It's really funny too, because sometimes they'll come with a PowerPoint presentation and a two-by-two matrix and an expected value and all that. But really they're asking the question of, "Hey, what should I do with my life," which is, by the way, a great question.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Highlights how people use analytical tools to mask a deeper values/identity decision—useful for recognizing when analysis is avoiding the real question.

quotes.topic_title: Why students ask: what should I do?
quotes.text: And after about five or 10 minutes into that, I can tell that their heart and their soul and their energy is really for B.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic: listen for energy and aliveness, not just pros/cons, to identify the option someone truly wants.

quotes.topic_title: Why students ask: what should I do?
quotes.text: So what I try to do is, A, first, I try to let them realize that their real energy is for B, just let them feel that and understand that.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Step one of his method: help the person notice and name their authentic preference before problem-solving.

quotes.topic_title: Why students ask: what should I do?
quotes.text: And then secondly, I try to figure out, what are the limiting beliefs they have? What are the fears? What are the obstacles? What are the voices in their head? What are all the societal pressures that are keeping them from doing B? And then we try to deconstruct those and get them to go do B.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Step two of his method: systematically surface and dismantle internal/external constraints blocking the desired path.

quotes.topic_title: Student example: choosing the nontraditional path
quotes.text: Okay, imagine you knew you were going to be successful and you were going to have a dream. And whatever you dreamed was going to come true, what would you dream for?
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A practical prompt (the “genie” style question) to surface what you’d pursue if fear and uncertainty were removed.

quotes.topic_title: Student example: choosing the nontraditional path
quotes.text: And over the course of our class, we just chipped away at all the fears and limiting beliefs of why he shouldn't or couldn't do that.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Highlights an actionable process: systematically identify and dismantle limiting beliefs over time rather than relying on a single burst of motivation.

quotes.topic_title: Student example: choosing the nontraditional path
quotes.text: it's not on the beaten path. It's not what probably your parents are thinking you should do. There's probably 100 reasons not to do it. You probably don't know exactly how to start, and so it's intimidating.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A memorable articulation of why meaningful, nontraditional paths feel hard—social pressure, uncertainty, and endless objections.

quotes.topic_title: Student example: choosing the nontraditional path
quotes.text: But if you start with this idea, "Hey, five years out, 10 years out, I know I'm going to be successful," and work backwards from that, you're going to come up with a better answer.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A concrete mental model: assume “guaranteed success,” then reverse-engineer decisions from that future to choose more boldly today.

quotes.topic_title: Genie framework: what would you do?
quotes.text: And the wish I can give you is whatever you throw yourself into with your whole life and your career, it's going to turn out great. It's going to work out great. It's probably going to take longer than you think. It's going to be harder than you think, but you're going to be really happy you did and it's going to work out beyond your wildest imagination." If that were true and you had that genie blessing you with that wish, what would you wish for?
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Defines the core “genie” prompt that removes fear of failure while still acknowledging difficulty and time, helping people choose a direction.

quotes.topic_title: Genie framework: what would you do?
quotes.text: And then the second part of the exercise is basically that's what you should go do. You should be spending your life in pursuit of your genie goal. Maybe you can't start that tomorrow; you have financial obligations, maybe there's some experience you need. But at some point in this one life we get, you want to get yourself on that path of that journey.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Turns the thought experiment into practical guidance: align your life toward the goal even if you need a staged transition.

quotes.topic_title: Genie framework: what would you do?
quotes.text: It's such a simple idea, that I can totally see how it could be so powerful. And I love the way it's framed as not like it'll guarantee you'll be successful. It's instead, I'll guarantee you'll be happy.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights the counterintuitive reframing from optimizing for external success to optimizing for lived satisfaction.

quotes.topic_title: Genie framework: what would you do?
quotes.text: And the reason I say that is that usually the genie goal is the not well-trodden path. So you don't even know exactly what the goal is.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Explains why the framework works: meaningful paths are often ambiguous and non-linear, so certainty isn’t a prerequisite to start.

quotes.topic_title: Genie framework: what would you do?
quotes.text: And that's the magic of it, because you have inside of you some really unique dream that you maybe haven't even shared. And the goal is that that's your uniqueness, and that's what you should be bringing into this world.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Encourages practitioners to treat their “unshared” ambitions as signal, and to build a life around their distinctive contribution.

quotes.topic_title: Autopilot living and becoming intentional
quotes.text: It's not a day that is intentional. It's not a day where I've said, "Where do I want to be going with my life? What's important to me in this world? What are my values? What 10 years from now will I wish I was starting to embark on?" Adding that level of intentionality and then working backwards from that is really the magic of getting to that 10 years from now and looking back without regret and getting to a later point in your life and feeling like you're doing the thing you're put on the earth to do as opposed to just going through the motions.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A practical framework: clarify values and long-term direction, then work backward to design your present actions to avoid regret.

quotes.topic_title: Autopilot living and becoming intentional
quotes.text: depending on what research you read, somewhere between 95% and 98% of our thoughts are subconscious.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A striking data point that reframes “autopilot” as the default state, motivating deliberate interventions.

quotes.topic_title: Autopilot living and becoming intentional
quotes.text: A big part of that, by the way, is media, our friends, our parents, our boss, our coworkers, what we think we're supposed to do, social media: "This is cool, buy this Ferrari," all these different things. And then you're just operating out of that.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Highlights the hidden sources of subconscious programming so practitioners can audit and reduce external influence.

quotes.topic_title: Autopilot living and becoming intentional
quotes.text: And so the idea of being intentional is create space, get out of that, get out of the fog of war, make some space. We'll probably get to this in a little bit, but I do it with an executive coach, and really ask deep questions, make space, ask questions, create the intention that you want in each of the areas of your life. And then start having your calendar reflect that intention.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: An actionable method: create space for deep questioning (often with a coach) and translate intentions into calendar commitments.

quotes.topic_title: Prompts to uncover your real interests
quotes.text: I mean, the biggest question I think with respect to your career is, within reason, what would you do if you knew you wouldn't fail?
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A high-leverage prompt for surfacing career directions you’re avoiding due to fear rather than lack of interest.

quotes.topic_title: Prompts to uncover your real interests
quotes.text: If you didn't have to make money, what would you do?
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A simple constraint-removal question to identify intrinsic motivation and what you genuinely enjoy.

quotes.topic_title: Prompts to uncover your real interests
quotes.text: Naval Ravikant has a great question, which is, what's play for you that is work for other people?
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for finding work you’ll naturally outcompete at because it feels like play.

quotes.topic_title: Prompts to uncover your real interests
quotes.text: Another one is, what's the thing you really want to do? But you're just too embarrassed to say it?
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A counterintuitive prompt that uses embarrassment as a signal for authentic desire and suppressed ambition.

quotes.topic_title: Prompts to uncover your real interests
quotes.text: So five, 10 years from now, you're amazing, you're best in the world at X. What's X? And how do you start to work toward becoming great at X?
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A practical long-horizon skill-targeting framework that turns vague growth into a concrete mastery plan.

quotes.topic_title: Limiting beliefs: write them down, defang them
quotes.text: The first thing I would say about limiting beliefs is they're the most powerful and the most dangerous when you don't even know what they are.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Highlights the core risk: unexamined beliefs drive behavior most when they’re invisible to you.

quotes.topic_title: Limiting beliefs: write them down, defang them
quotes.text: So the first exercise is just write all that down.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Gives a concrete first step for surfacing and externalizing limiting beliefs so you can work with them.

quotes.topic_title: Limiting beliefs: write them down, defang them
quotes.text: One is when you get it down on paper, it will almost immediately strip that limiting belief of a lot of its power and a lot of its scariness.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Explains the mechanism: writing reduces emotional charge and makes fears less intimidating.

quotes.topic_title: Limiting beliefs: write them down, defang them
quotes.text: Once it's on paper, now it's just a to-do item that you can actually deal with with your conscious mind, just like you do anything else.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Provides a practical reframing method: convert vague fears into actionable tasks.

quotes.topic_title: Limiting beliefs: write them down, defang them
quotes.text: So the first part of limiting beliefs, write them down, understand what they are, look at them in the cold day of light on paper, and then translate them into things that are just obstacles to be overcome.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Summarizes a repeatable process for defanging limiting beliefs and turning them into solvable obstacles.

quotes.topic_title: Teaching as a Trojan horse for fulfillment
quotes.text: After about four years, I started to realize that was great, except that no one went and did it. So the class is on entrepreneurship, and they learned how to be an entrepreneur. There was only one problem: they didn't actually become entrepreneurs.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Highlights the common gap between learning tactics and actually taking action—useful for anyone designing training, coaching, or personal development plans.

quotes.topic_title: Teaching as a Trojan horse for fulfillment
quotes.text: So then I said, "Well, wait a sec. I have to readjust my class a little bit, and I have to spend some time on the stuff we've just been talking about: finding out what your dream is, your limiting beliefs, starting to map out goals toward your actual entrepreneurship dream or whatever your genie goal is."
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Provides an actionable methodology: clarify the dream, surface limiting beliefs, and map goals toward the real objective (the “genie goal”).

quotes.topic_title: Teaching as a Trojan horse for fulfillment
quotes.text: So the way I say it is the university allows me to teach the class because I teach them entrepreneurial tricks, tactics, tools that will help them become a great CEO. But the real reason I teach is because I'm trying to help people really go find the thing that they're excited about and get into the life path of doing that thing.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A “Trojan horse” model for change: lead with practical skills, but use them to guide people toward deeper alignment and fulfillment.

quotes.topic_title: Teaching as a Trojan horse for fulfillment
quotes.text: Tony Robbins used to say that people hire him for success, and he has to give them that so that he feels like he earned his money, but what he really delivers them is fulfillment.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A memorable reframing for practitioners: deliver the stated goal (success) while designing for the deeper outcome (fulfillment).

quotes.topic_title: Internal vs external scorecards and long timelines
quotes.text: I think about it as you have sort of your heart or your soul or your internal scorecard, and then you have your head and your mind and the world's external scorecard.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Introduces a practical framework for choosing between internally meaningful goals and externally validated “safe” paths.

quotes.topic_title: Internal vs external scorecards and long timelines
quotes.text: The problem was it wasn't my internal scorecard. It had nothing to do with what I actually cared about and wanted to do with my life. And so the way that shows up is just this tension, friction, stress, anxiety, burnout, all those things. And you can will that, you can will yourself through for long periods of time. In fact, if you want, you can will yourself through that your whole life.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Explains the predictable psychological cost of living by an external scorecard—and the trap of enduring it indefinitely through willpower.

quotes.topic_title: Internal vs external scorecards and long timelines
quotes.text: But what I would say is that the formula you're solving for is you, excited about something for a decade or more.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Reframes career planning as an optimization problem around sustained motivation over long timelines.

quotes.topic_title: Internal vs external scorecards and long timelines
quotes.text: So the missing ingredient in most of the people that fail is time.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A counterintuitive diagnosis that persistence over time—not just talent or strategy—is often the decisive factor.

quotes.topic_title: Internal vs external scorecards and long timelines
quotes.text: But long story short, I was 14 years into running my firm until I could say with confidence we were going to even stay in business, let alone be really successful. And probably 18 years until we were what I would say really successful by external standards.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Provides a concrete timeline example that challenges “overnight success” narratives and sets realistic expectations.

quotes.topic_title: Life is suffering; everything is worse first
quotes.text: So yeah, the quote, "Life is suffering. So figure out something worth suffering for," you're going to suffer either way.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A values-based decision rule: since hardship is inevitable, choose goals and work that feel meaningful enough to endure it.

quotes.topic_title: Life is suffering; everything is worse first
quotes.text: The second one, everything you want is on the other side of worst first, and this is something where I almost can't think of many exceptions to this.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A mental model for change: expect an initial dip and treat “worse first” as a sign you’re on the right path, not a reason to quit.

quotes.topic_title: Life is suffering; everything is worse first
quotes.text: In each case, the first move is negative.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for tough decisions: the correct first step often feels like a loss (discomfort, effort, awkwardness) before benefits appear.

quotes.topic_title: Life is suffering; everything is worse first
quotes.text: So if you realize this and instead ask the question, the version of myself five years from now, what would they wish I was going to do right now?
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A concrete decision-making technique: use your future self as a compass to override short-term comfort optimization.

quotes.topic_title: Life is suffering; everything is worse first
quotes.text: But if you don't do that, you just end up plateauing.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A warning about the cost of avoidance: refusing the “hard day/month” locks people into long-term stagnation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With ready-made, collaborative features, you can supercharge your product with experiences that only top tier companies have been able to perfect until now.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a practical approach—adding prebuilt collaboration—to quickly elevate product experience without building everything from scratch.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Think AI copilots like Notion, multiplayer like Figma, comments and notifications like Linear, and even collaborative editing like Google Docs, and all of that with minimal configuration or maintenance required.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Provides concrete examples of high-engagement collaboration patterns teams can emulate and ship with low overhead.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Companies from all kinds of industries and stages count on Liveblocks to drive engagement and growth in their products.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Suggests a broadly applicable lever for product growth: collaboration features that increase engagement across contexts.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Join them today and give your users an experience that turns them into daily active users.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Frames a clear outcome metric (DAU) tied to improving the in-product experience, useful for product prioritization.

quotes.topic_title: Accountability systems: coaches, friends, weekly forms
quotes.text: The formula, I think, for greatness is to be intentional, get in the path of the thing that you're most excited about, and then give yourself several decades to do it.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A simple, time-horizon-based framework for achieving outsized results by combining intention, alignment, and patience.

quotes.topic_title: Accountability systems: coaches, friends, weekly forms
quotes.text: The equivalent of that in your life is an executive coach.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A memorable analogy that reframes coaching as a practical accountability system, not a luxury.

quotes.topic_title: Accountability systems: coaches, friends, weekly forms
quotes.text: I have one coach that I can't even have the call with the coach unless I fill out a piece of paper or an online form that says, "Here's what my one year goals are, outcomes I want to have this year are. Here's what I did last week, based on those. Here's what I'm going to do next week toward those. And here's the outcomes I want to have for the call we're about to have."
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A concrete weekly template practitioners can copy to force clarity and follow-through before accountability check-ins.

quotes.topic_title: Accountability systems: coaches, friends, weekly forms
quotes.text: There's another thing that happens that's kind of magical, which is you activate a different part of your brain when you talk. You actually activate more of your brain when you talk than when you think or write. So thinking activates the least amount of your brain. Writing is a little bit better, but talking activates a whole different region of your brain.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A counterintuitive rationale for why accountability partners/coaches can outperform solo journaling or private reflection.

quotes.topic_title: Accountability systems: coaches, friends, weekly forms
quotes.text: I'd say this to all your listeners: you will get more done writing down your goal and three things you're going to do to move toward that goal, you'll get more things done in three months than you will in three years without that.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A punchy, actionable practice (“goal + 3 actions”) with a strong claim about its leverage over time.

quotes.topic_title: Nine lives exercise and avoiding “not now”
quotes.text: There's two rules. The first rule is all the lives have to start from today. So you can't go back in time. They all start from today. And the second rule is you have to be excited about all these lives.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Defines the core constraints that make the “nine lives” exercise practical and motivating rather than nostalgic or obligation-driven.

quotes.topic_title: Nine lives exercise and avoiding “not now”
quotes.text: There might be one of these lives that gives you the most energy, and it's the thing if you knew you wouldn't fail, you would do this one. And it's good to recognize what that is and then pull that life a little bit into your current life.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Offers a concrete method for de-risking big changes: identify the highest-energy path and bring a small piece of it into your current situation now.

quotes.topic_title: Nine lives exercise and avoiding “not now”
quotes.text: Forget if you ever do this full time or not; just the act of pulling something into your life you're really excited about will give you a tremendous amount of energy.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Reframes side projects as an energy and momentum generator, not merely a stepping stone to quitting your job.

quotes.topic_title: Nine lives exercise and avoiding “not now”
quotes.text: Instead, they say, "Not now." And not now, if they're not careful, will turn into not ever, because not now is just really another way of saying, "I'm not going to do it."
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: A memorable warning that procrastination often disguises avoidance, helping people recognize when “timing” is actually fear.

quotes.topic_title: Nine lives exercise and avoiding “not now”
quotes.text: And if you wait for the clouds to part and this ray of sun to come down and say, "Now is the time," you're going to wait your whole life.
quotes.speaker: Graham Weaver
quotes.context: Counters the common belief that you should wait for certainty before acting, emphasizing that uncertainty is normal in meaningful change.
